title: What are some Japanese names that name death? - Quora

response.answer_text: I assume you mean person’s names. This page has a list of kanji which are related to death. - 亜(a)A tomb of an aristocrat. Ugly. Having a bad look. Stutter. examples of names : 亜子(Ako), 実亜(Mia), 亜留斗(Aruto) - 久(ku, hisa)This hieroglyph means a tree is supporting a body or a sick person. Used also for a coffin(柩) or sickness(疚). Means illness or disabilities. examples of names : 凌久(Riku), 久哉(Hisaya), 久美(Kumi) - 眞(makoto, ma)The dead who died from a disaster. The upper part 匕 means a body upside down and the lower part 県 its hair hanging from it. examples of names : 眞(makoto), 眞菜(mana) - 了(ryo)This hieroglyph means an infant wrapped with his/her limbs. Some say it is a child with his/her arms cut down. examples of names : 了(Ryo, Satoru, Akira), 了華(Ryoka), 美了愛(Miria) - 七(nana)This hieroglyph means being stabbed vertically and horizontally. examples of names : 七海(Nanami), 七々子(Nanako), 七斗(Nanato), 星七(Sena)

I am not sure what you mean. Do you mean to ask a question similar to “What are some English names that name professions” and the answer would be “Smith, Taylor, Butler, Butcher, and Baker for example?" If you had asked the same question of English names, then I am not aware of any English names that name death, and death is even more taboo here in Japan than it is in the UK. However, at a tangent perhaps, and if the pun four (shi) is of relevance then surnames pronounced Shibou written 四坊, 芝生 puns on a more academic word for death (死亡）as does (interestingly) the Japanese word for ovary. The womb is a tomb in Japanese too. Alternatively if you not looking for names of people then there are many other words for death and dying as there is in English, such as takai suru (lit. do/go to the other world), yuku (go or die when written with a special character), naku naru (become nothing / de-become?!), sossuru (graduate!), Kokeru (fall), and kotogiru (run out of things). Some of these too pun with names such as Takai meaning high well 高井, 高居 High place to be, 鷹居 hawks place to be (nest) which is at least a placename. And Yuki a conjunction of Yuku, to go, is a common given name for both boys and more often girls. It is written with other characters to give it other meanings but it puns on “going.” As for proper names of death itself, there is also Yominokuni, the country of death which probably originates in the yo of yoru meaning night, perhaps the country where one sees the night. The characters for Yomi mean literally, Yellowspring. There are people that call themselves this on the net but not as a real surname (afaik).
